column4: 2025|3370673|Analysts|Toni Kaplan|175144|79637153.0|Executives|Martina Cheung|429194|640442511.0|118252387|118252388|22|25.0|23|"I wanted to go back to Market Intelligence as well. Martina
column5: you said in the prepared remarks
column6: you're experiencing a highly competitive environment and elevated price sensitivity in MI. I was just hoping to get just a little bit more color on that. Which -- are there specific areas of Market Intelligence seeing more competition?

column2: I know it is always a competitive space. And are you seeing sort of start-ups or large vendors more competing on price or just coming into the market? Just anything on the competitive angle would be helpful in the pricing as well."|114|Toni
column3: thanks so much for your question. I would say that the comment in the prepared remarks is largely a reflection on what we were seeing in the financial end markets. We commented throughout the course of last year that in addition to the softness -- somewhat softness in the markets that we did see increased competition and price sensitivity. Now all that being said
column4: in Q4
column5: we saw a couple of trends
column6: which are important for us and things that we want to continue to focus on. The first is our competitive breadth in terms of all of the products that we can bring
column7: not just within Market Intelligence
column8: but we're also seeing opportunities to connect in other products
column9: for example
column10: Commodity Insights products. That breadth allows us to position ourselves for opportunities where we can benefit from vendor consolidation activity with our clients. We want to make sure we're very focused on that going forward. Another thing I would say is that we have an opportunity here
column11: and we're seeing it already in the conversations that have taken place through the Chief Client Office
column12: but we think that there could be some good opportunities here just to make sure that we're bringing everything that we can to our clients. In some cases
column13: our clients may not even know the full picture of how they can benefit from the products and services that they're purchasing from us. And so the strengthened -- strengthening the relationships is a way for us to make sure they're getting the most value and that we're getting opportunities to demonstrate more ways to create value for them. So that's on the competitive environment
column14: but also how we differentiate ourselves. I think on price
column15: we believe we have a very differentiated set of capabilities
column16: and we will always try to align the price with the value that we create for the -- for our clients. Obviously
column17: we don't sort of guide forward on that. But that's really a -- at the intersection of the value we create for our clients and the economics that we have with them. Thanks for the question.|417|"[

and thank you for joining today's S&P Global Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2024 Earnings Call. Any such statements are based on current expectations and current economic conditions and are subject to risks and uncertainties and that may cause actual results to differ materially from results anticipated in these forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning these risks and uncertainties can be found in our Forms 10-K and 10-Q filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. column3: we are providing non-GAAP adjusted financial information. This information is provided to enable investors to make meaningful comparisons of the company's operating performance between periods and to view the company's business from the same perspective as management. Any investor who has or expects to obtain ownership of 5% or more of S&P Global should contact Investor Relations to better understand the potential impact of this legislation on the investor and the company. column15: which allowed us to make important investments in technology
column16: AI and products while still expanding margins more than 300 basis points. We delivered 25% growth in adjusted EPS in 2024. In total
column17: you'll see this would allow us to maintain our target of returning 85% or more of the $6 billion in adjusted free cash flow we are expecting in 2025. I've been very impressed with our people's ability to execute and deliver such strong results

Our base case assumption is that we see at least one more rate cut this year in the U.S. We recognize that market expectations around the pace of 2025 breakups have moderated over the last several months. But as we've seen in recent years
column153: these rate movements are difficult to predict with a high degree of confidence. Turning to our most recent refinancing study. The maturities expected over the next 3 years
column154: however
column155: are approximately 1% lower than they were 12 months ago. Our billed issuance forecast takes both of these rates into account. The maturity walls make up just one of the factors we consider when providing an outlook on billed issuance. Given the record issuance here we've had and the deceleration we are expecting in 2025
column156: we wanted to provide some additional context around our outlook for low single-digit growth in billed issuance. Importantly
column157: we saw an acceleration in the pull forward of the 2025 maturity wall during the fourth quarter
column158: which impacts our outlook in 2 ways. First
column159: it drove stronger issuance than we expected during the fourth quarter of 2024. We saw that in our financial results
column160: and it creates a more difficult compare this year. Second

column162: and we are encouraged by the robust maturity walls over the next few years

column175: as billed issuance growth and modest price increases are somewhat offset by expected unfavorable mix of billed issuance. We continue to take a balanced approach to investments and profitability in Ratings. In Commodity Insights
column176: we expect revenue growth in the range of 7% to 8.5% and margins in the range of 47% to 48%. We expect continued robust demand for our energy transition products as well as our market-leading Platts price assessments. Given the long runway and secular tailwinds in this business
column177: we continue to invest to further distance ourselves from competitors in this space. In Mobility
column178: we expect continued strong growth in the range of 7% to 8.5%. We have reinvested revenue upside in the last couple of years
column180: but we expect the necessary pace of investment to slow somewhat in 2025. Lastly
column182: our guidance assumes relatively flat equity asset prices from the end of 2024
column183: given the very strong returns in the S&P 500 over the last 2 years. As such
column184: we expect revenue growth in the range of 8% to 10%. Given margins are already above our medium-term targets and given the attractive slate of investment opportunities in Indices
column185: we are making the decision to reinvest incremental profit for future growth in 2025. I refer you to our supplemental materials on our Investor Relations website for some additional details on our financial guidance
column186: but we are also expecting to deliver approximately $6 billion in adjusted free cash flow in 2020. This does create a difficult compare for working capital and free cash flow growth in 2025
column187: but we expect to maintain a free cash flow conversion rate at or above 100% in 2025 as well. In closing
column188: through the various leadership roles I've held over the last 15 years within S&P Global
column189: I've seen the ins and outs of our businesses up close at every stage of the cycle. Our company sits at the crossroads with so many vitally important secular trends: data and artificial intelligence

column192: fixed income and commodities. We have the right people in place
column193: we are making the right investments
column194: and we are building the right strategy. It's an incredibly exciting time to be at S&P Global. With that

column20: the only other point I would make just on the issuance point is just calling your attention to the fact that we expect a slight skew towards investment grade. And of course
column21: if that comes under frequent issuer programs
column22: you wouldn't see it in the billed issuance guide. And then maybe just the other point on non-transaction
column23: we'd expect to see that grow around the same level as the transaction
column24: driven primarily by surveillance fees.""

column1: ""content"": ""I wanted to focus on the margins. Margins are now -- the margin guidance are more at the higher end of the midterm guidance and was better than
column2: I think
column3: what we were expecting. You mentioned a disciplined approach to expense management as well as balanced approach in investments and profitability
column4: both in MI and Ratings. How should we think about the incremental margins going forward and not only for '25
column5: but over the next several years?""

column1: ""content"": ""And maybe just to take a step back
column2: we were obviously very pleased with the 2024 full year results on margins and achieving our IR Day margin range. We -- as you see from our guidance in 2025
column3: we're at the high end of the guidance range from IR Day
column4: and that is several factors. First
column5: we are extremely disciplined around expense management. One of the core operating motions for this leadership team is making sure that we are putting every next dollar to work in the place where we can see the greatest return for value creation for our customers
column6: but also long-term shareholder value
column7: and that is giving us some ideas around how we can actually be more efficient. We're looking at location strategy. We're looking at efficiency throughout our infrastructure
column8: our cloud spend
column9: et cetera. And then
column10: very importantly
column11: we're integrating AI across the organization. Every one of those users is finding ways to spend less time doing some of the more mundane tasks and more time on the value-added tasks. And some of that productivity gain is reflected in the margin guidance that we provided today. We do spend a fair amount of time looking at the incremental margins. And it's worth noting that as a market-driven business
column12: we have reasonably high incremental margins in the high double digits.""

column1: ""content"": ""I wanted to go back to Market Intelligence as well. Martina
column2: you said in the prepared remarks
column3: you're experiencing a highly competitive environment and elevated price sensitivity in MI. I was just hoping to get just a little bit more color on that. Which -- are there specific areas of Market Intelligence seeing more competition? And previously
column4: I know it is always a competitive space. And are you seeing sort of start-ups or large vendors more competing on price or just coming into the market? Just anything on the competitive angle would be helpful in the pricing as well.""

column1: ""content"": ""I would say that the comment in the prepared remarks is largely a reflection on what we were seeing in the financial end markets. We commented throughout the course of last year that in addition to the softness -- somewhat softness in the markets that we did see increased competition and price sensitivity. Now all that being said
column2: in Q4
column3: we saw a couple of trends
column4: which are important for us and things that we want to continue to focus on. The first is our competitive breadth in terms of all of the products that we can bring
column5: not just within Market Intelligence
column6: but we're also seeing opportunities to connect in other products
column7: for example
column8: Commodity Insights products. That breadth allows us to position ourselves for opportunities where we can benefit from vendor consolidation activity with our clients. Another thing I would say is that we have an opportunity here
column9: and we're seeing it already in the conversations that have taken place through the Chief Client Office
column10: but we think that there could be some good opportunities here just to make sure that we're bringing everything that we can to our clients. In some cases
column11: our clients may not even know the full picture of how they can benefit from the products and services that they're purchasing from us. So that's on the competitive environment
column12: but also how we differentiate ourselves. I think on price
column13: we believe we have a very differentiated set of capabilities
column14: and we will always try to align the price with the value that we create for the -- for our clients. But that's really a -- at the intersection of the value we create for our clients and the economics that we have with them.""

column1: ""content"": ""From the perspective of a top executive
column2: please answer the following question raised by a financial analyst during an earnings conference call. Knowledge cutoff date: 2025-02-11""
and thank you for joining today's S&P Global Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2024 Earnings Call. In addition
column3: we have posted a supplemental slide deck with additional information on our results and guidance. Any such statements are based on current expectations and current economic conditions and are subject to risks and uncertainties and that may cause actual results to differ materially from results anticipated in these forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning these risks and uncertainties can be found in our Forms 10-K and 10-Q filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. In today's press release and during the conference call
column4: we are providing non-GAAP adjusted financial information. This information is provided to enable investors to make meaningful comparisons of the company's operating performance between periods and to view the company's business from the same perspective as management. The press release contains financial measures calculated in accordance with GAAP that corresponds to the non-GAAP measures we are providing
column5: and the press release and the supplemental deck contain reconciliations of such GAAP and non-GAAP measures. The financial metrics we'll be discussing today refer to non-GAAP adjusted metrics
column6: unless explicitly noted otherwise. We are aware that we have some media representatives with us on the call. However
column7: this call is intended for investors
column8: and we would ask that questions from the media be directed to our Media Relations team
column9: whose contact information can be found in the press release. Excluding Engineering Solutions
column10: which was divested in 2023
column11: revenue increased 15%
column12: and revenue from our subscription products increased 7%. We benefited from strong market trends
column13: including record debt issuance for our Ratings business and strong equity valuations for our index business. However
column14: we also continue to demonstrate the discipline and operational excellence our shareholders have come to expect from us
column15: delivering accelerated revenue growth in Commodity Insights and strong steady growth in both Market Intelligence and Mobility
column16: despite some market headwinds on those 2 businesses. We continue to take a balanced approach to profitability and investment
column17: which allowed us to make important investments in technology
column18: AI and products while still expanding margins more than 300 basis points. We delivered 25% growth in adjusted EPS in 2024. In total
column19: you'll see this would allow us to maintain our target of returning 85% or more of the $6 billion in adjusted free cash flow we are expecting in 2025. I've been very impressed with our people's ability to execute and deliver such strong results
column20: embracing the leadership transition and the increased focus on our customers and our enterprise advantages. With that increased focus on serving our clients at the enterprise level
column21: we announced the establishment of the Chief Client Office and the Enterprise Data Office. We are gaining momentum in our product innovation and AI initiatives across the organization as well
column22: as I'll share with you in a moment. Lastly
column23: we continue the cycle of optimizing our portfolio of businesses
column24: so that we are best positioned for long-term profitable growth. One of my first priorities as CEO was to strengthen and deepen our relationship with key strategic customers at the highest levels of leadership. These important discussions include not just our customers
column25: but also strategic
column26: commercial and technology partners. Together with our new Chief Client Officer
column27: I met 85% of our largest strategic customers just in the last 100 days. We are instilling in our executive leadership team
column28: a clear need to be where our customers are. Our success depends on the value we create and deliver for our customers
column29: so I've asked our division leadership to make these relationships a personal priority for them as well. This emphasis on customer engagement is a natural evolution for S&P Global. We've always made customer value a focus. But by making customer engagement a higher priority at the executive level
column30: we are building stronger relationships
column31: so that we can accelerate our response to customers' challenges. This engagement can also serve as opportunities to partner or co-invest with our customers. While generative AI is not a new topic for our customers
column32: they're moving beyond just considering what this technology can do and focusing on use cases that can scale quickly and contribute to strong financial results. Customers increasingly turn to us to benefit from our years of experience scaling AI technology from Kensho. We continue to see impactful headlines and market news on a near daily basis. Customers continue to feel the impact of the innovation taking place in financial markets with the flow of capital to passive funds
column33: but also increasingly to private markets and digital assets. For example
column34: in utilities
column35: the depth and breadth of our expertise and data sets across oil
column36: liquid natural gas
column37: carbon
column38: renewable energy
column39: electric utilities and reporting all helped drive the 23% growth in revenue from our energy transition and sustainability products in the fourth quarter. As we look to 2025
column40: we are hearing general expectations for some improvements in the macroeconomic environment. There is some variability by geographic region here
column41: with caution and uncertainty around Europe and Asia
column42: providing some ballast against the general optimism we're seeing in the U.S. markets. We are seeing strong demand for our products and some modest tailwinds from vendor consolidation. We continue to see the benefits from the breadth of our offerings
column43: as our enterprise approach allows us to meet more of our customers' needs in a more cost-effective way. As we've discussed for some time now
column44: we continue to see conditions in the financial services end market below what we would consider normal
column45: though we do expect a gradual improvement over the course of the year. We are also experiencing a highly competitive environment in financial services and somewhat elevated price sensitivity
column46: most notably impacting Market Intelligence. We saw many issuers take advantage in 2024 to refinance debt and felt very strong activity in CLO volumes as well as repricing and amend and extend activity. While this does create a very difficult compare for 2025
column47: we believe the refinancing walls and a recovering M&A environment will contribute to modest growth in build issuance this year
column48: as we'll discuss in more detail in a moment. As we look next to the Vitality Index
column49: I'm encouraged that this index continues to accomplish its intended purpose. When we introduced this metric at our Investor Day in 2022
column50: we discussed the importance of making sure we were prioritizing new products that can contribute to our financial performance over time. We also noted that new products would remain in the Vitality Index for a finite time and would eventually mature out. The focus is to make sure that revenue from maturing products is replaced by new and enhanced products that can scale quickly. At the beginning of 2024
column51: we had a number of meaningful products mature out of the Vitality Index. By continuing to innovate and invest in fast growing products
column52: we were able to more than replace that mature revenue and end the year with an index of $1.5 billion
column53: representing nearly 11% of total revenue. At the end of 2024

column55: and we are confident that our focus on customer value and rapid innovation will once again enable us to deliver a Vitality Index at or above 10% this year. Turning to just a few examples of that innovation. As the world's leading provider of benchmarks
column56: we continue to invest and innovate to launch new benchmark products and make our existing benchmarks better. We know that data and technology lay at the heart of almost everything we do
column57: so we continue to make meaningful investments in our internal technology and our technology products. Part of our focus on technology must include a strategy to leverage the incredible technological advancement taking place in the world today
column58: such as generative AI. We are continuing to build a culture that embraces AI
column59: and we are empowering our people with the tools
column60: training and resources they need to thrive. We firmly believe that as we embrace the use of AI internally

column62: tools and resources that improve our productivity and efficiency will likely benefit our customers as well. Through ongoing customer meetings

column64: again and again

This is all part of our ongoing effort to bring our data into this new era of GenAI and ensure that we are meeting customers where they are and where they are going in their AI journeys. We also identified and acquired market-leading solutions that we believe strengthen our competitive position in multiple areas
column66: while contributing to the immediate financial results of the company. With the ultimate goal of driving profitable long-term revenue growth
column67: we will continue to lean into these kinds of innovation: development of tools for our own efficiency and productivity
column68: organic development of new products for our customers
column69: partnerships to develop new products and token acquisitions to accelerate the pace of scale and leadership. You'll notice that across these examples of innovation runs a common thread of generative AI. When we look at the potential for generative AI across the business over the next several years
column70: there are seemingly endless opportunities to innovate and add value for our customers. And with all this possibility
column71: we will ensure that S&P Global remains an indispensable partner to our customers as they adopt AI into more and more of their workloads. We're doing this in many ways
column72: including building sophisticated GenAI experiences
column73: laying the groundwork for agentive workflows and investing in foundational AI capabilities that help our customers more quickly and effectively gain insights from our data. In the coming quarters and years

column75: improve our operational productivity and efficiency
column76: improve the capabilities and skills of our people and safeguard the security around our proprietary data and our systems. This will require us to say no to a lot of things
column77: but will allow us to effectively put investment dollars to work in ways that have the greatest potential to create real value. Now turning to our financial results. Chris will walk through the fourth quarter results in more detail in a moment
column78: but we are pleased and encouraged by the results we delivered for our shareholders in 2024. We continue to see strong growth in our market-driven and our subscription businesses

column81: we saw some elevated expenses in 2024 related to incentive compensation and commissions due to the very strong revenue beat this year. Were it not for that increase in compensation expense
column82: we would have had year-over-year margin expansion in every division. Now I'll turn to Chris to review the financial results. We finished 2024 with strong results as fourth quarter revenue grew by 14% compared to the prior year
column83: with growth across all of our divisions. Notably
column84: our market-driven businesses
column85: Ratings and Indices each grew by over 20% in the quarter as we capitalized on favorable conditions in both the debt and equity markets. This is driven by a combination of our strong revenue growth
column86: margin expansion of 260 basis points and a 2% reduction in fully diluted share count. Now turning to strategic investment areas
column87: where I'm excited to share that there was positive momentum across our key initiatives
column88: all of which are helping drive sustainable growth for the company. Growth was driven primarily by strong performance in Commodity Insights energy transition offerings and positive fund flows and sustainability focused indices. In Private Markets Solutions
column89: revenue growth accelerated to 29% to $146 million in the fourth quarter. Growth was driven primarily by continued strong demand for our private market ratings and assessments within S&P Global Ratings. During the quarter
column90: we realized $74 million in revenue synergies. We are pleased to see both cross-sell and new product revenue synergies coming in above our expectations in Q4. Finally
column91: we generated approximately $409 million in Vitality revenue during the fourth quarter
column92: resulting in an 11% Vitality Index. As previously highlighted
column93: we anticipate a steady stream of innovative offerings to replace any products graduating from the index
column94: ensuring sustained momentum in our product lineup. We saw a total increase of 9% in the fourth quarter. This is primarily driven by ongoing investments in our core business and growth initiatives
column95: coupled with increased incentives
column96: commissions and compensation. The significant outperformance in our Ratings and Indices divisions during the fourth quarter increased incentive compensation across the enterprise. Market Intelligence revenue increased 5% in the fourth quarter or 6% excluding acquisitions and divestitures
column97: with positive revenue growth in every business line. We continue to see the effect of cancellations early in 2024 impacting revenue growth in the fourth quarter. We also had significant competitive wins in each of the business lines in Market Intelligence and no significant competitive losses. Importantly

This resulted in operating profit increasing by 12% for the quarter and operating margin expanding by 100 basis points to 34.7%. Revenue increased 21%

column138: and our financial results reflect that. As we look to 2025 and beyond
column139: the innovation and investment that we made in 2024 position us very well to continue delivering long-term profitable growth and create meaningful value for our shareholders. These all represent some degree of mean reversion from the figures we've seen over the last couple of years
column140: which we think should contribute to a stable issuance environment and a gradually improving backdrop for our financial services customers as we progress through 2025. We acknowledge
column141: however
column142: the degree of macro and geopolitical uncertainty that exists right now and that there is a range of potential outcomes beyond our base case assumptions. Our base case assumption is that we see at least one more rate cut this year in the U.S. We recognize that market expectations around the pace of 2025 breakups have moderated over the last several months. But as we've seen in recent years
column143: these rate movements are difficult to predict with a high degree of confidence. As such
column144: we are taking a prudent approach to our forecast for billed issuance. We expect low single-digit growth in billed issuance in 2025 from a record high base in 2024. Turning to our most recent refinancing study. The maturities expected over the next 3 years
column145: however
column146: are approximately 1% lower than they were 12 months ago. The maturity walls make up just one of the factors we consider when providing an outlook on billed issuance. Given the record issuance here we've had and the deceleration we are expecting in 2025
column147: we wanted to provide some additional context around our outlook for low single-digit growth in billed issuance. Importantly
column148: we saw an acceleration in the pull forward of the 2025 maturity wall during the fourth quarter
column149: which impacts our outlook in 2 ways. First
column150: it drove stronger issuance than we expected during the fourth quarter of 2024. We saw that in our financial results
column151: and it creates a more difficult compare this year. Second
column152: it obviously decreases the amount of near-term maturities that are available to get refinanced in 2025. We also expect some improvement in the M&A environment relative to the last couple of years
column153: and there should be some tailwinds to issuance as a result. Lastly
column154: our expectation is that the mix of issuance is likely to shift slightly in favor of investment grade compared to what we saw in 2024. Against that backdrop
column155: we are introducing our financial guidance for 2025. This slide illustrates our guidance for GAAP results. We expect revenue growth in the range of 5% to 7% in 2025. In Market Intelligence
column156: we expect revenue growth in the range of 5% to 6.5%. We exited 2024 with a very strong renewal quarter
column157: with the highest retention rate we've seen in the last 6 quarters. That sets up the subscription business for improving growth
column158: but we would still be lapping the elevated cancellations from the prior quarters. As a result
column159: we expect the growth rate to be the lowest in the first quarter and improve as we progress through the year. Due to the timing of revenue recognition
column160: the lapping of acquisitions and divestitures and the phasing of investments
column161: we also expect margins to be the lowest in the first quarter. For Ratings
column162: we expect revenue growth in the range of 3% to 5%
column163: as billed issuance growth and modest price increases are somewhat offset by expected unfavorable mix of billed issuance. We continue to take a balanced approach to investments and profitability in Ratings. And through continued expense discipline and improved efficiencies
column164: we expect to deliver margins in the range of 63% to 64%
column165: despite the slower expected growth in 2025. In Commodity Insights
column166: we expect revenue growth in the range of 7% to 8.5% and margins in the range of 47% to 48%. Given the long runway and secular tailwinds in this business
column167: we continue to invest to further distance ourselves from competitors in this space. In Mobility
column168: we expect continued strong growth in the range of 7% to 8.5%. We have reinvested revenue upside in the last couple of years
column169: which has tempered margin expansion
column170: but we expect the necessary pace of investment to slow somewhat in 2025. Lastly
column172: our guidance assumes relatively flat equity asset prices from the end of 2024
column173: given the very strong returns in the S&P 500 over the last 2 years. As such
column174: we expect revenue growth in the range of 8% to 10%. Given margins are already above our medium-term targets and given the attractive slate of investment opportunities in Indices
column175: we are making the decision to reinvest incremental profit for future growth in 2025. I refer you to our supplemental materials on our Investor Relations website for some additional details on our financial guidance
column176: but we are also expecting to deliver approximately $6 billion in adjusted free cash flow in 2020. This does create a difficult compare for working capital and free cash flow growth in 2025
column177: but we expect to maintain a free cash flow conversion rate at or above 100% in 2025 as well. In closing
column178: through the various leadership roles I've held over the last 15 years within S&P Global
column179: I've seen the ins and outs of our businesses up close at every stage of the cycle. Our company sits at the crossroads with so many vitally important secular trends: data and artificial intelligence
column181: active to passive management and public and private market dynamics. We have the right people in place
column182: we are making the right investments
column183: and we are building the right strategy. It's an incredibly exciting time to be at S&P Global. With that
column184: we will turn the call back over to Mark for your questions.""

column18: we'd expect to see that grow around the same level as the transaction

column150: we are introducing our financial guidance for 2025. This slide illustrates our guidance for GAAP results. Moving to our adjusted guidance. Turning to our outlook by division. We exited 2024 with a very strong renewal quarter

column152: but we would still be lapping the elevated cancellations from the prior quarters. As a result

column154: the lapping of acquisitions and divestitures and the phasing of investments
column155: we also expect margins to be the lowest in the first quarter. We continue to take a balanced approach to investments and profitability in Ratings. We expect continued robust demand for our energy transition products as well as our market-leading Platts price assessments. Given the long runway and secular tailwinds in this business
column156: we continue to invest to further distance ourselves from competitors in this space. In Mobility
column157: we expect continued strong growth in the range of 7% to 8.5%. We have reinvested revenue upside in the last couple of years
column158: which has tempered margin expansion
column159: but we expect the necessary pace of investment to slow somewhat in 2025. As such
column160: we expect revenue growth in the range of 8% to 10%. Given margins are already above our medium-term targets and given the attractive slate of investment opportunities in Indices
column161: we are making the decision to reinvest incremental profit for future growth in 2025. In closing
column162: through the various leadership roles I've held over the last 15 years within S&P Global
column163: I've seen the ins and outs of our businesses up close at every stage of the cycle. Our company sits at the crossroads with so many vitally important secular trends: data and artificial intelligence

column165: active to passive management and public and private market dynamics. We also sit at the nexus of all the major global markets: equity

column167: we are making the right investments
column168: and we are building the right strategy. It's an incredibly exciting time to be at S&P Global. With that

column15: AI and products while still expanding margins more than 300 basis points. In total

column96: primarily due to increased incentive compensation. This resulted in a 42% increase in operating profit and a 630 basis point increase in operating margin to 59.7%. For the full year
column97: Ratings margin expanded 650 basis points to 63%. And now turning to Commodity Insights. Revenue increased 10%
column98: driven by double-digit growth in Energy & Resources Data & Insights and Advisory & Transactional services. Growth was driven by strength in our traditional offerings
column99: such as our crude and refined product suite. In addition
column100: both business lines continue to benefit from favorable commercial conditions. Adjusted expenses increased 9%. Operating profit for Commodity Insights increased 11%
column101: and operating margin expanded by 60 basis points to 45%. Full year margin increased by 70 basis points to 46.8%. And now turning to Mobility. Manufacturing revenue increased 1% as the business line continued to see lower transaction revenue related to our Recall business
column102: offsetting strong growth in our subscription-based offerings. Growth in financials and other accelerated to 18% as the business line benefited from strong underwriting volumes and market share growth. Adjusted expenses increased 7%. This resulted in operating profit increasing by 12% for the quarter and operating margin expanding by 100 basis points to 34.7%. Full year margin increased by 20 basis points to 39%. Now turning to S&P Dow Jones Indices. Revenue increased 21%
column103: primarily driven by growth in asset-linked fees
column104: which benefited from higher AUM as well as growth in Data & Custom Subscriptions. Asset-linked fees were up 31%
column105: driven by market appreciation and inflows. Data & Custom Subscriptions increased 5% year-over-year as we continue to implement commercial initiatives across the various product offerings within the business line. However
column106: growth in the fourth quarter was partially offset by a retrospective revenue adjustment. Excluding the impact of this onetime headwind
column107: Data & Custom Subscriptions would have grown by 10%. Adjusted expenses increased 15% year-over-year
column108: primarily due to increased incentive compensation
column109: combined with continued investment in our strategic growth initiatives. Indices operating profit increased 24%
column110: and operating margin expanded by 180 basis points to 67.9%. For the full year
column111: Indices operating margin expanded by 140 basis points to 70.3%. 2024 was a tremendous year
column112: and our financial results reflect that. As we look to 2025 and beyond
column113: the innovation and investment that we made in 2024 position us very well to continue delivering long-term profitable growth and create meaningful value for our shareholders. With that
column114: I'll hand it back to Martina to walk through the outlook and the guidance. Thank you
column115: Chris. These all represent some degree of mean reversion from the figures we've seen over the last couple of years
column116: which we think should contribute to a stable issuance environment and a gradually improving backdrop for our financial services customers as we progress through 2025. We acknowledge
column117: however
column118: the degree of macro and geopolitical uncertainty that exists right now and that there is a range of potential outcomes beyond our base case assumptions. Our base case assumption is that we see at least one more rate cut this year in the U.S. We recognize that market expectations around the pace of 2025 breakups have moderated over the last several months. But as we've seen in recent years
column119: these rate movements are difficult to predict with a high degree of confidence. As such
column120: we are taking a prudent approach to our forecast for billed issuance. Turning to our most recent refinancing study. The maturities expected over the next 3 years
column121: however
column122: are approximately 1% lower than they were 12 months ago. Our billed issuance forecast takes both of these rates into account. The maturity walls make up just one of the factors we consider when providing an outlook on billed issuance. Given the record issuance here we've had and the deceleration we are expecting in 2025
column123: we wanted to provide some additional context around our outlook for low single-digit growth in billed issuance. Importantly
column124: we saw an acceleration in the pull forward of the 2025 maturity wall during the fourth quarter
column125: which impacts our outlook in 2 ways. First
column126: it drove stronger issuance than we expected during the fourth quarter of 2024. We saw that in our financial results
column127: and it creates a more difficult compare this year. Second
column128: it obviously decreases the amount of near-term maturities that are available to get refinanced in 2025. We also expect some improvement in the M&A environment relative to the last couple of years
column129: and there should be some tailwinds to issuance as a result. Lastly
column130: our expectation is that the mix of issuance is likely to shift slightly in favor of investment grade compared to what we saw in 2024. Against that backdrop
column131: we are introducing our financial guidance for 2025. This slide illustrates our guidance for GAAP results. Moving to our adjusted guidance. We expect adjusted operating margin in the range of 49% to 50%
column132: which represents up to 100 basis points of margin expansion beyond the high profitability level reported in 2024. Turning to our outlook by division. We exited 2024 with a very strong renewal quarter
column133: with the highest retention rate we've seen in the last 6 quarters. That sets up the subscription business for improving growth
column134: but we would still be lapping the elevated cancellations from the prior quarters. As a result
column135: we expect the growth rate to be the lowest in the first quarter and improve as we progress through the year. Due to the timing of revenue recognition
column136: the lapping of acquisitions and divestitures and the phasing of investments
column137: we also expect margins to be the lowest in the first quarter. We continue to take a balanced approach to investments and profitability in Ratings. And through continued expense discipline and improved efficiencies
column138: we expect to deliver margins in the range of 63% to 64%
column139: despite the slower expected growth in 2025. Given the long runway and secular tailwinds in this business
column140: we continue to invest to further distance ourselves from competitors in this space. We have reinvested revenue upside in the last couple of years
column141: which has tempered margin expansion
column142: but we expect the necessary pace of investment to slow somewhat in 2025. As such
column143: we are expecting margins in the range of 39% to 40%
column144: representing approximately 50 basis points of margin expansion at the midpoint. Lastly
column145: in Indices
column146: our guidance assumes relatively flat equity asset prices from the end of 2024
column147: given the very strong returns in the S&P 500 over the last 2 years. As such
column148: we expect revenue growth in the range of 8% to 10%. Given margins are already above our medium-term targets and given the attractive slate of investment opportunities in Indices
column149: we are making the decision to reinvest incremental profit for future growth in 2025. As a result
column150: we expect margins to remain relatively flat to 2024 levels and are guiding to a range of 69.5% to 70.5%. I refer you to our supplemental materials on our Investor Relations website for some additional details on our financial guidance
column151: but we are also expecting to deliver approximately $6 billion in adjusted free cash flow in 2020. In closing
column152: through the various leadership roles I've held over the last 15 years within S&P Global
column153: I've seen the ins and outs of our businesses up close at every stage of the cycle. We also sit at the nexus of all the major global markets: equity
column154: fixed income and commodities. We have the right people in place
column155: we are making the right investments
column156: and we are building the right strategy. It's an incredibly exciting time to be at S&P Global. With that
column157: we will turn the call back over to Mark for your questions.""

column2: Q4 2024 Earnings Call
column3: Feb 11
column5: you talked about private credit being a major TAM opportunity in Ratings previously. Can you provide an update on where you are in terms of executing on this opportunity? Wondering if you can be specific perhaps around how much revenue private credit is contributing to Ratings right now.

column1: Any thoughts around sort of cadence of growth
column2: new products you're working on here
column3: conversations with the private credit houses would be useful. And perhaps
column4: just on a separate note
column5: do you have any view on the TAM opportunity for the Ratings business that might come if Fannie and Freddie are privatized?"|119|Russell
column6: thanks so much for the question. So private credit
column7: indeed
column8: in Ratings has been a strong opportunity. One of the things that we have also said in addition to recognizing that opportunity is that we would rate deals wherever they come
column9: whether it's in the public market or the private markets. We also
column10: of course
column11: recognized back in 2022 the absolute importance of making sure that we were engaged at the right levels with the private market issuers
column12: and we've been very focused on that. You see that reflected in the results. The strong growth in the overall credit revenues for S&P Global were very much reflecting the strong growth in Ratings. I would say that we have an incredible overall breadth of solutions around the private markets
column13: in addition to private credit
column14: and that's something that we're excited about as we go forward. It's the software businesses
column15: the marquee businesses
column16: Wall Street Office eye level
column17: but it's also the valuation solutions that we offer
column18: which are very much in demand. It's the private indices and the opportunity to innovate further there as well as the work that we're doing in credit ratings. And so I would say we would see a continuation of the hard work that the teams are doing across the divisions. We don't break out the revenue numbers by division
column19: but this continues to be a top area of focus for us. And I think on your last question with respect to Fannie and Freddie
column20: we're not going to speculate right now what that could look like. But certainly
column21: if there are more facts coming to the table on that
column22: we'll certainly get back to you on it. All right. So I'm going to go to some closing remarks. I want to say thanks so much for everybody joining us. I'm incredibly proud of our colleagues' performance in 2024. We've had incredible execution and great results. Our people are focused on the right priorities
column23: customer engagement and rapid innovation. I do want to pause a second and give just a really
column24: really special thank you to Chris Craig for his work as Interim CFO. I have enjoyed working with Chris for every minute of that Interim CFO time period and look forward to continuing to work with you. And then looking ahead
column25: our focus remains clear. We have a really collaborative leadership team that is focused on delivering customer value. We're building on our legacy of disciplined execution. We have solid 2025 guidance
column26: and we're going to continue to create long-term profitable growth and shareholder value. And so let me just say this is the beginning. With our unparalleled data and technology
column27: our benchmarks and our people
column28: we're going to continue to unlock our potential
column29: and I look forward to sharing more. Thank you.|581|"[

column1: ""content"": ""From the perspective of a top executive
column2: please answer the following question raised by a financial analyst during an earnings conference call. Knowledge cutoff date: 2025-02-11""

and thank you for joining today's S&P Global Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2024 Earnings Call. The matters discussed in today's conference call may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995
column3: including projections
column4: estimates and descriptions of future events. Any such statements are based on current expectations and current economic conditions and are subject to risks and uncertainties and that may cause actual results to differ materially from results anticipated in these forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning these risks and uncertainties can be found in our Forms 10-K and 10-Q filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. In today's press release and during the conference call
column5: we are providing non-GAAP adjusted financial information. This information is provided to enable investors to make meaningful comparisons of the company's operating performance between periods and to view the company's business from the same perspective as management. The financial metrics we'll be discussing today refer to non-GAAP adjusted metrics
column6: unless explicitly noted otherwise. Any investor who has or expects to obtain ownership of 5% or more of S&P Global should contact Investor Relations to better understand the potential impact of this legislation on the investor and the company. We are aware that we have some media representatives with us on the call. However

column8: and we would ask that questions from the media be directed to our Media Relations team
column9: whose contact information can be found in the press release. At this time

column11: 2024 was an incredible year for S&P Global. We benefited from strong market trends
column12: including record debt issuance for our Ratings business and strong equity valuations for our index business. However
column13: we also continue to demonstrate the discipline and operational excellence our shareholders have come to expect from us

column15: despite some market headwinds on those 2 businesses. We continue to take a balanced approach to profitability and investment
column16: which allowed us to make important investments in technology
column17: AI and products while still expanding margins more than 300 basis points. We delivered 25% growth in adjusted EPS in 2024. In total
column18: you'll see this would allow us to maintain our target of returning 85% or more of the $6 billion in adjusted free cash flow we are expecting in 2025. I've been very impressed with our people's ability to execute and deliver such strong results
column19: embracing the leadership transition and the increased focus on our customers and our enterprise advantages. With that increased focus on serving our clients at the enterprise level

column21: as I'll share with you in a moment. Lastly

column23: so that we are best positioned for long-term profitable growth. We also divested noncore businesses

We've always made customer value a focus. But by making customer engagement a higher priority at the executive level

column31: they're moving beyond just considering what this technology can do and focusing on use cases that can scale quickly and contribute to strong financial results. S&P Global is a world-class provider of data insights and thought leadership in these vital areas

Turning to our most recent refinancing study. Our billed issuance forecast takes both of these rates into account. The maturity walls make up just one of the factors we consider when providing an outlook on billed issuance. Given the record issuance here we've had and the deceleration we are expecting in 2025

Our outlook for the Ratings division assumes the refinancing of 2025 maturities and modest pull forward from the 2026 and later maturities. We also expect some improvement in the M&A environment relative to the last couple of years

column7: and that is giving us some ideas around how we can actually be more efficient. We're looking at location strategy. We're looking at efficiency throughout our infrastructure
column8: our cloud spend

And some of that productivity gain is reflected in the margin guidance that we provided today. We do spend a fair amount of time looking at the incremental margins. And it's worth noting that as a market-driven business
column12: we have reasonably high incremental margins in the high double digits.""

column1: ""content"": ""We issued a press release with our results earlier today. In addition
column2: we have posted a supplemental slide deck with additional information on our results and guidance. Any such statements are based on current expectations and current economic conditions and are subject to risks and uncertainties and that may cause actual results to differ materially from results anticipated in these forward-looking statements. In today's press release and during the conference call
column3: we are providing non-GAAP adjusted financial information. This information is provided to enable investors to make meaningful comparisons of the company's operating performance between periods and to view the company's business from the same perspective as management. The financial metrics we'll be discussing today refer to non-GAAP adjusted metrics
column4: unless explicitly noted otherwise. I would also like to call your attention to certain European regulations. We are aware that we have some media representatives with us on the call. However
column5: this call is intended for investors
column6: and we would ask that questions from the media be directed to our Media Relations team
column7: whose contact information can be found in the press release. At this time
column8: I would like to turn the call over to Martina Cheung. Thank you
column9: Mark. We benefited from strong market trends
column10: including record debt issuance for our Ratings business and strong equity valuations for our index business. However
column11: we also continue to demonstrate the discipline and operational excellence our shareholders have come to expect from us
column12: delivering accelerated revenue growth in Commodity Insights and strong steady growth in both Market Intelligence and Mobility
column13: despite some market headwinds on those 2 businesses. We continue to take a balanced approach to profitability and investment
column14: which allowed us to make important investments in technology
column15: AI and products while still expanding margins more than 300 basis points. We delivered 25% growth in adjusted EPS in 2024. This exceeded the midpoint of our initial guidance range by more than 13%. In total
column16: you'll see this would allow us to maintain our target of returning 85% or more of the $6 billion in adjusted free cash flow we are expecting in 2025. I've been very impressed with our people's ability to execute and deliver such strong results
column17: embracing the leadership transition and the increased focus on our customers and our enterprise advantages. We're excited to share the successes from these initiatives with you as we progress through the year. We are gaining momentum in our product innovation and AI initiatives across the organization as well
column18: as I'll share with you in a moment. Lastly
column19: we continue the cycle of optimizing our portfolio of businesses
column20: so that we are best positioned for long-term profitable growth. One of my first priorities as CEO was to strengthen and deepen our relationship with key strategic customers at the highest levels of leadership. I had more than 100 meetings with some of our most important stakeholders to ensure a smooth transition of these key relationships. These important discussions include not just our customers
column21: but also strategic
column22: commercial and technology partners. Together with our new Chief Client Officer
column23: I met 85% of our largest strategic customers just in the last 100 days. We are instilling in our executive leadership team
column24: a clear need to be where our customers are. Our success depends on the value we create and deliver for our customers
column25: so I've asked our division leadership to make these relationships a personal priority for them as well. This emphasis on customer engagement is a natural evolution for S&P Global. We've always made customer value a focus. This engagement can also serve as opportunities to partner or co-invest with our customers. Through these many meetings
column26: I'm picking up a consistent set of themes
column27: which align very well with our competitive advantages and reinvigorate our optimism and confidence in our ability to compete and win. We continue to see impactful headlines and market news on a near daily basis. Customers continue to feel the impact of the innovation taking place in financial markets with the flow of capital to passive funds
column28: but also increasingly to private markets and digital assets. Additionally
column29: customers recognize our leadership and seek our insights in energy transition. As we look to 2025
column30: we are hearing general expectations for some improvements in the macroeconomic environment. There is some variability by geographic region here
column31: with caution and uncertainty around Europe and Asia
column32: providing some ballast against the general optimism we're seeing in the U.S. markets. We are seeing strong demand for our products and some modest tailwinds from vendor consolidation. We continue to see the benefits from the breadth of our offerings
column33: as our enterprise approach allows us to meet more of our customers' needs in a more cost-effective way. As we've discussed for some time now
column34: we continue to see conditions in the financial services end market below what we would consider normal
column35: though we do expect a gradual improvement over the course of the year. We are also experiencing a highly competitive environment in financial services and somewhat elevated price sensitivity
column36: most notably impacting Market Intelligence. Now turning to the 2024 issuance environment. While this does create a very difficult compare for 2025
column37: we believe the refinancing walls and a recovering M&A environment will contribute to modest growth in build issuance this year
column38: as we'll discuss in more detail in a moment. As we look next to the Vitality Index
column39: I'm encouraged that this index continues to accomplish its intended purpose. When we introduced this metric at our Investor Day in 2022
column40: we discussed the importance of making sure we were prioritizing new products that can contribute to our financial performance over time. We also noted that new products would remain in the Vitality Index for a finite time and would eventually mature out. The focus is to make sure that revenue from maturing products is replaced by new and enhanced products that can scale quickly. At the beginning of 2024
column41: we had a number of meaningful products mature out of the Vitality Index. By continuing to innovate and invest in fast growing products

column45: and we are confident that our focus on customer value and rapid innovation will once again enable us to deliver a Vitality Index at or above 10% this year. Turning to just a few examples of that innovation. As the world's leading provider of benchmarks
column46: we continue to invest and innovate to launch new benchmark products and make our existing benchmarks better. We know that data and technology lay at the heart of almost everything we do
column47: so we continue to make meaningful investments in our internal technology and our technology products. Part of our focus on technology must include a strategy to leverage the incredible technological advancement taking place in the world today
column48: such as generative AI. First
column49: beginning with our people. We are continuing to build a culture that embraces AI
column50: and we are empowering our people with the tools

and thank you for joining today's S&P Global Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2024 Earnings Call. The matters discussed in today's conference call may contain forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995
column3: including projections
column4: estimates and descriptions of future events. Any such statements are based on current expectations and current economic conditions and are subject to risks and uncertainties and that may cause actual results to differ materially from results anticipated in these forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning these risks and uncertainties can be found in our Forms 10-K and 10-Q filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. In today's press release and during the conference call
column5: we are providing non-GAAP adjusted financial information. This information is provided to enable investors to make meaningful comparisons of the company's operating performance between periods and to view the company's business from the same perspective as management. The press release contains financial measures calculated in accordance with GAAP that corresponds to the non-GAAP measures we are providing
column6: and the press release and the supplemental deck contain reconciliations of such GAAP and non-GAAP measures. The financial metrics we'll be discussing today refer to non-GAAP adjusted metrics
column7: unless explicitly noted otherwise. Any investor who has or expects to obtain ownership of 5% or more of S&P Global should contact Investor Relations to better understand the potential impact of this legislation on the investor and the company. However
column8: this call is intended for investors
column9: and we would ask that questions from the media be directed to our Media Relations team
column10: whose contact information can be found in the press release. By any measure
column11: 2024 was an incredible year for S&P Global. Excluding Engineering Solutions
column12: which was divested in 2023
column13: revenue increased 15%
column14: and revenue from our subscription products increased 7%. We benefited from strong market trends
column15: including record debt issuance for our Ratings business and strong equity valuations for our index business. However
column16: we also continue to demonstrate the discipline and operational excellence our shareholders have come to expect from us
column17: delivering accelerated revenue growth in Commodity Insights and strong steady growth in both Market Intelligence and Mobility
column18: despite some market headwinds on those 2 businesses. We continue to take a balanced approach to profitability and investment
column19: which allowed us to make important investments in technology
column20: AI and products while still expanding margins more than 300 basis points. We delivered 25% growth in adjusted EPS in 2024. We expect to continue strong capital returns in 2025
column21: as we recently announced the 52nd consecutive increase to our cash dividend and a newly approved share repurchase authorization up to $4.3 billion. In total
column22: you'll see this would allow us to maintain our target of returning 85% or more of the $6 billion in adjusted free cash flow we are expecting in 2025. I've been very impressed with our people's ability to execute and deliver such strong results
column23: embracing the leadership transition and the increased focus on our customers and our enterprise advantages. With that increased focus on serving our clients at the enterprise level
column24: we announced the establishment of the Chief Client Office and the Enterprise Data Office. We are gaining momentum in our product innovation and AI initiatives across the organization as well
column25: as I'll share with you in a moment. Lastly
column26: we continue the cycle of optimizing our portfolio of businesses
column27: so that we are best positioned for long-term profitable growth. These important discussions include not just our customers
column28: but also strategic
column29: commercial and technology partners. Together with our new Chief Client Officer
column30: I met 85% of our largest strategic customers just in the last 100 days. This emphasis on customer engagement is a natural evolution for S&P Global. We've always made customer value a focus. But by making customer engagement a higher priority at the executive level
column31: we are building stronger relationships
column32: so that we can accelerate our response to customers' challenges. This engagement can also serve as opportunities to partner or co-invest with our customers. While generative AI is not a new topic for our customers
column33: they're moving beyond just considering what this technology can do and focusing on use cases that can scale quickly and contribute to strong financial results. We continue to see impactful headlines and market news on a near daily basis. Customers continue to feel the impact of the innovation taking place in financial markets with the flow of capital to passive funds
column34: but also increasingly to private markets and digital assets. Through our leadership in benchmarks
column35: private credit
column36: private equity workflow tools and innovation like our Stablecoin Assessments
column37: our customers see us as a critical partner in navigating this sea change over the coming years. For example
column38: in utilities
column39: the depth and breadth of our expertise and data sets across oil
column40: liquid natural gas
column41: carbon
column42: renewable energy
column43: electric utilities and reporting all helped drive the 23% growth in revenue from our energy transition and sustainability products in the fourth quarter. As we look to 2025
column44: we are hearing general expectations for some improvements in the macroeconomic environment. There is some variability by geographic region here
column45: with caution and uncertainty around Europe and Asia
column46: providing some ballast against the general optimism we're seeing in the U.S. markets. We are seeing strong demand for our products and some modest tailwinds from vendor consolidation. We continue to see the benefits from the breadth of our offerings
column47: as our enterprise approach allows us to meet more of our customers' needs in a more cost-effective way. As we've discussed for some time now
column48: we continue to see conditions in the financial services end market below what we would consider normal
column49: though we do expect a gradual improvement over the course of the year. We are also experiencing a highly competitive environment in financial services and somewhat elevated price sensitivity
column50: most notably impacting Market Intelligence. Now turning to the 2024 issuance environment. We saw nearly $4 trillion in billed issuance in 2024
column51: significantly outpacing our expectations
column52: with extremely favorable market conditions

column1: ""content"": ""From the perspective of a top executive

and thank you for joining today's S&P Global Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2024 Earnings Call. In today's press release and during the conference call
column3: we are providing non-GAAP adjusted financial information. This information is provided to enable investors to make meaningful comparisons of the company's operating performance between periods and to view the company's business from the same perspective as management. The financial metrics we'll be discussing today refer to non-GAAP adjusted metrics
column4: unless explicitly noted otherwise. Any investor who has or expects to obtain ownership of 5% or more of S&P Global should contact Investor Relations to better understand the potential impact of this legislation on the investor and the company. However

column10: revenue increased 15%
column11: and revenue from our subscription products increased 7%. We benefited from strong market trends
column12: including record debt issuance for our Ratings business and strong equity valuations for our index business. However

column16: which allowed us to make important investments in technology

Our disciplined approach to capital allocation allowed us to return $4.4 billion to shareholders over the course of 2024 through our cash dividend and the repurchase of 6.7 million shares. We expect to continue strong capital returns in 2025
column18: as we recently announced the 52nd consecutive increase to our cash dividend and a newly approved share repurchase authorization up to $4.3 billion. In total

column1: ""content"": ""From the perspective of a top executive
column2: please answer the following question raised by a financial analyst during an earnings conference call. Knowledge cutoff date: 2025-02-11""
and thank you for joining today's S&P Global Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2024 Earnings Call. In today's press release and during the conference call
column3: we are providing non-GAAP adjusted financial information. This information is provided to enable investors to make meaningful comparisons of the company's operating performance between periods and to view the company's business from the same perspective as management. The financial metrics we'll be discussing today refer to non-GAAP adjusted metrics
column4: unless explicitly noted otherwise. Any investor who has or expects to obtain ownership of 5% or more of S&P Global should contact Investor Relations to better understand the potential impact of this legislation on the investor and the company. However
column5: this call is intended for investors
column6: and we would ask that questions from the media be directed to our Media Relations team
column7: whose contact information can be found in the press release. By any measure
column8: 2024 was an incredible year for S&P Global. Excluding Engineering Solutions
column9: which was divested in 2023
column10: revenue increased 15%
column11: and revenue from our subscription products increased 7%. We benefited from strong market trends
column12: including record debt issuance for our Ratings business and strong equity valuations for our index business. However
column13: we also continue to demonstrate the discipline and operational excellence our shareholders have come to expect from us
column14: delivering accelerated revenue growth in Commodity Insights and strong steady growth in both Market Intelligence and Mobility
column15: despite some market headwinds on those 2 businesses. We continue to take a balanced approach to profitability and investment
column16: which allowed us to make important investments in technology
column17: AI and products while still expanding margins more than 300 basis points. We delivered 25% growth in adjusted EPS in 2024. Our disciplined approach to capital allocation allowed us to return $4.4 billion to shareholders over the course of 2024 through our cash dividend and the repurchase of 6.7 million shares. We expect to continue strong capital returns in 2025
column18: as we recently announced the 52nd consecutive increase to our cash dividend and a newly approved share repurchase authorization up to $4.3 billion. In total
column19: you'll see this would allow us to maintain our target of returning 85% or more of the $6 billion in adjusted free cash flow we are expecting in 2025. I've been very impressed with our people's ability to execute and deliver such strong results
column20: embracing the leadership transition and the increased focus on our customers and our enterprise advantages. We are gaining momentum in our product innovation and AI initiatives across the organization as well
column21: as I'll share with you in a moment. Lastly
column22: we continue the cycle of optimizing our portfolio of businesses
column23: so that we are best positioned for long-term profitable growth. One of my first priorities as CEO was to strengthen and deepen our relationship with key strategic customers at the highest levels of leadership. Together with our new Chief Client Officer
column24: I met 85% of our largest strategic customers just in the last 100 days. We are instilling in our executive leadership team
column25: a clear need to be where our customers are. Our success depends on the value we create and deliver for our customers
column26: so I've asked our division leadership to make these relationships a personal priority for them as well. This emphasis on customer engagement is a natural evolution for S&P Global. We've always made customer value a focus. But by making customer engagement a higher priority at the executive level
column27: we are building stronger relationships
column28: so that we can accelerate our response to customers' challenges. This engagement can also serve as opportunities to partner or co-invest with our customers. While generative AI is not a new topic for our customers
column29: they're moving beyond just considering what this technology can do and focusing on use cases that can scale quickly and contribute to strong financial results. We continue to see impactful headlines and market news on a near daily basis. Customers continue to feel the impact of the innovation taking place in financial markets with the flow of capital to passive funds
column30: but also increasingly to private markets and digital assets. Through our leadership in benchmarks
column31: private credit
column32: private equity workflow tools and innovation like our Stablecoin Assessments
column33: our customers see us as a critical partner in navigating this sea change over the coming years. For example
column34: in utilities
column35: the depth and breadth of our expertise and data sets across oil
column36: liquid natural gas
column37: carbon
column38: renewable energy
column39: electric utilities and reporting all helped drive the 23% growth in revenue from our energy transition and sustainability products in the fourth quarter. As we look to 2025
column40: we are hearing general expectations for some improvements in the macroeconomic environment. There is some variability by geographic region here
column41: with caution and uncertainty around Europe and Asia
column42: providing some ballast against the general optimism we're seeing in the U.S. markets. As we've discussed for some time now
column43: we continue to see conditions in the financial services end market below what we would consider normal
column44: though we do expect a gradual improvement over the course of the year. We are also experiencing a highly competitive environment in financial services and somewhat elevated price sensitivity
column45: most notably impacting Market Intelligence. We saw nearly $4 trillion in billed issuance in 2024
column46: significantly outpacing our expectations
column47: with extremely favorable market conditions
column48: including tight credit spreads and lowering interest rates. We saw many issuers take advantage in 2024 to refinance debt and felt very strong activity in CLO volumes as well as repricing and amend and extend activity. While this does create a very difficult compare for 2025

column50: as we'll discuss in more detail in a moment. As we look next to the Vitality Index
column51: I'm encouraged that this index continues to accomplish its intended purpose. When we introduced this metric at our Investor Day in 2022
column52: we discussed the importance of making sure we were prioritizing new products that can contribute to our financial performance over time. The focus is to make sure that revenue from maturing products is replaced by new and enhanced products that can scale quickly. By continuing to innovate and invest in fast growing products

column56: and we are confident that our focus on customer value and rapid innovation will once again enable us to deliver a Vitality Index at or above 10% this year. In 2024

column61: in 2024 was the introduction of the market fixed income securities data in Capital IQ Pro. Part of our focus on technology must include a strategy to leverage the incredible technological advancement taking place in the world today
column62: such as generative AI. We are continuing to build a culture that embraces AI

column64: training and resources they need to thrive. As we focus on developing AI skills across our entire workforce
column65: we are seeing our people truly embrace the use of these powerful tools to automate workflows

column68: we hear

This is all part of our ongoing effort to bring our data into this new era of GenAI and ensure that we are meeting customers where they are and where they are going in their AI journeys. We also identified and acquired market-leading solutions that we believe strengthen our competitive position in multiple areas
column71: while contributing to the immediate financial results of the company. With the ultimate goal of driving profitable long-term revenue growth

You'll notice that across these examples of innovation runs a common thread of generative AI. When we look at the potential for generative AI across the business over the next several years
column75: there are seemingly endless opportunities to innovate and add value for our customers. And with all this possibility
column76: we will ensure that S&P Global remains an indispensable partner to our customers as they adopt AI into more and more of their workloads. We're doing this in many ways

column83: but we are pleased and encouraged by the results we delivered for our shareholders in 2024. We continue to see strong growth in our market-driven and our subscription businesses

column158: the degree of macro and geopolitical uncertainty that exists right now and that there is a range of potential outcomes beyond our base case assumptions. Our base case assumption is that we see at least one more rate cut this year in the U.S. We recognize that market expectations around the pace of 2025 breakups have moderated over the last several months. The maturity walls make up just one of the factors we consider when providing an outlook on billed issuance. Given the record issuance here we've had and the deceleration we are expecting in 2025
column159: we wanted to provide some additional context around our outlook for low single-digit growth in billed issuance. Importantly
column160: we saw an acceleration in the pull forward of the 2025 maturity wall during the fourth quarter
column161: which impacts our outlook in 2 ways. First
column162: it drove stronger issuance than we expected during the fourth quarter of 2024. We saw that in our financial results
column163: and it creates a more difficult compare this year. Second
column164: it obviously decreases the amount of near-term maturities that are available to get refinanced in 2025. We continue to expect favorable market conditions around stable rates and credit spreads
column165: and we are encouraged by the robust maturity walls over the next few years
column166: all of which inspires confidence that issuance will see positive growth in 2025. We also expect some improvement in the M&A environment relative to the last couple of years
column167: and there should be some tailwinds to issuance as a result. Lastly
column168: our expectation is that the mix of issuance is likely to shift slightly in favor of investment grade compared to what we saw in 2024. This slide illustrates our guidance for GAAP results. We expect revenue growth in the range of 5% to 7% in 2025. We expect adjusted operating margin in the range of 49% to 50%
column169: which represents up to 100 basis points of margin expansion beyond the high profitability level reported in 2024. Through a combination of robust organic revenue growth

column172: representing double-digit growth at the high end. In Market Intelligence

column175: but we would still be lapping the elevated cancellations from the prior quarters. As a result

column177: the lapping of acquisitions and divestitures and the phasing of investments
